title: Evolving Theory in Interprofessional Education
abstractText:
Changes in healthcare services have led to an increase in interprofessional teamworking but a range of high profile public inquiries have demonstrated that these teams do not always collaborate optimally. To adequately prepare health professionals in this area, interprofessional education (IPE) has become a mandatory component of their training. However, the evidence base and theoretical underpinnings of this field remain limited. Significant momentum developed in this area through an ESRC-funded series of four workshops (2007-2009) that provided opportunity to prioritise, evolve and apply theory to IPE, in the presence of key theoretical experts.

The seminar series comprised 4 workshops each lead by a key note speaker expert in a particular theoretical perspective followed by group work to apply this theory to IPE practice.

  • Seminar 1 presented an overview of social psychology, sociology and education perspectives, comparing and contrasting these and exploring criteria with which to prioritise these.
  • Seminar 2 focused on the relevance of contact hypothesis, social identity and psychodynamics to the IPE context. 
  • Seminar 3 explored the application of transtheoretical models and activity theory to  IPE.
  • Seminar 4 summarised key messages of the past three seminars and reflected on the way forward for theory development in this area.
